cleaned_text: Energy (esotericism) |Part of |[Paranormal](/wiki/Paranormal) |This article is part of |[Alternative medicine](/wiki/Alternative_medicine) Proponents and practitioners of various [esoteric](/wiki/Esoteric) forms of [spirituality](/wiki/Spirituality) and [alternative medicine](/wiki/Alternative_medicine) refer to a variety of claimed experiences and phenomena as being due to "energy" or "force" that defy measurement and thus are distinguished from the scientific form of [energy](/wiki/Energy). [[1]](#cite_note-Stenger-1) [[2]](#cite_note-Smith-2) Claims related to energy therapies are most often [anecdotal](/wiki/Anecdotal_evidence), rather than being based on repeatable [empirical](/wiki/Empirical) evidence. [[3]](#cite_note-energy-3) [[4]](#cite_note-Barrett-4) [[5]](#cite_note-Jarvis-5) There is no [scientific evidence](/wiki/Scientific_evidence) for the existence of such energy, [[2]](#cite_note-Smith-2) [[1]](#cite_note-Stenger-1) and physics educators criticize the use of the term "energy" to describe ideas in esotericism and sprituality as potentially confusing. [[6]](#cite_note-arias-6) History[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Energy_(esotericism)&action=edit§ion=1)] force", " [qi](/wiki/Qi)" and " [élan vital](/wiki/%C3%89lan_vital)" existed from antiquity. In the 18th century, [Franz Mesmer](/wiki/Franz_Mesmer) ignited debate with his theory of [animal magnetism](/wiki/Animal_magnetism). Attention to [vitalism](/wiki/Vitalism) grew in the 18th and 19th centuries. Interest continued into the 20th century, largely fuelled by adherents of the [New Age](/wiki/New_Age) movement. [[1]](#cite_note-Stenger-1) [[2]](#cite_note-Smith-2) As biologists studied [embryology](/wiki/Embryology) and [developmental biology](/wiki/Developmental_biology), particularly before the discovery of genes, a variety of organisational forces were posited to account for their observations. German biologist [Hans Driesch](/wiki/Hans_Driesch) (1867-1941), proposed [entelechy](/wiki/Hans_Driesch#The_philosophy_of_entelechy), an energy which he believed controlled organic processes. [[7]](#cite_note-Vitalism-7)[ [unreliable source](/wiki/Wikipedia:Reliable_sources)] However such ideas are discredited and modern [science](/wiki/Science) has all but abandoned the attempt to associate additional energetic properties with [life](/wiki/Life). [[7]](#cite_note-Vitalism-7) It is not the scientific concept of energy that is being referred to in the context of spirituality and alternative medicine. As [Brian Dunning](/wiki/Brian_Dunning_(author)) writes: That's all that energy is: a measurement of work capability. But in popular culture, 'energy' has somehow become a noun. "Energy" is often spoken of as if it is a thing unto itself, like a region of glowing power, that can be contained and used. Here's a good test. When you hear the word "energy" used, substitute the phrase "measurable work capability". Does the usage still make sense? Remember, energy itself is not the thing being measured: energy is the measurement of work performed or of potential... Thus, this New Age concept of the body having an "energy field" is fatally doomed. There is no such thing as an energy field; they are two unrelated concepts. [[8]] Despite the lack of scientific support, spiritual writers and thinkers have maintained ideas about energy and continue to promote them either as useful allegories or as fact. [[9]](#cite_note-9) The field of [energy medicine](/wiki/Energy_medicine) purports to manipulate energy, but there is no credible evidence to support this. [[3]](#cite_note-energy-3) The concept of "qi" (energy) appears throughout traditional [East Asian](/wiki/East_Asia) [culture](/wiki/East_Asian_cultural_sphere), such as in the art of [feng shui](/wiki/Feng_shui) and [Chinese martial arts](/wiki/Chinese_martial_arts). [[10]](#cite_note-10) Qi philosophy also includes the notion of "negative qi", typically understood as introducing negative [moods](/wiki/Mood_(psychology)) like outright [fear](/wiki/Fear) or more moderate expressions like [social anxiety](/wiki/Social_anxiety) or [awkwardness](/wiki/Awkwardness). [[11]](#cite_note-Norden2011-11) Deflecting this negative qi through [geomancy](/wiki/Geomancy) is a preoccupation in [feng shui](/wiki/Feng_shui). [[12]](#cite_note-Leonard-12) The traditional explanation of [acupuncture](/wiki/Acupuncture) states that it works by manipulating the circulation of qi through a network of [meridians](/wiki/Meridian_(Chinese_medicine)). [[13]](#cite_note-13) Locations[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Energy_(esotericism)&action=edit§ion=2)] There are various [sacred natural sites](/wiki/Sacred_natural_site) that people of various belief systems find [numinous](/wiki/Numen) or having an "energy" with significance to humans. [[14]](#cite_note-14) The idea that some kind of "negative energy" is responsible for creating or attracting [ghosts](/wiki/Ghost) or [demons](/wiki/Demon) appears in contemporary paranormal culture and beliefs as exemplified in the TV shows [Paranormal State](/wiki/Paranormal_State) 1999).
